ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about bird behavior as well as the process of scientific field research and experimental design.
General background in bird behavior (also just animal behavior in general). Skills in thinking about and analyzing scientific literature
Lots of experience reading and discussing scientific papers.
I developed a working knowledge of literature from select topics in ornithology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a unique and interesting class. Only having two assignments made it nice in terms of workload but difficult in terms of knowing how I was doing. Discussion and content were interesting but each class was a different topic so some were more enjoyable than others. Each week being different gave little continuity, but that can be a benefit too

Professor Prum's background in the field made the course. In addition to explaining the concepts in the paper, he was able to provide additional information about the historical trends within the field.

I think that one of the biggest strengths of this course was the instructor. Rick is a phenomenal scientist, and an excellent resource for anyone interested in birds. The discussions over Zoom were a bit difficult, but that's not unique to this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that the online seminar format worked well.
Was pretty similar to how it would be in person

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend the course for a student who has an active interest in birds, behavior, the history of science, and scientific study design.
Definitely if interested in animal behavior and thinking about scientific papers
I thoroughly enjoyed the course. I have a fairly strong biology background, but other who did not may have different opinions on the course.
If you have an interest in birds, I'd say this course would be right up your alley. Rick is fantastic. But if you don't like birds, I'd suggest looking for other options.
